reviewText: A huge THANK YOU to Shout Factory for securing the rights to the rest of the classic ALL IN THE FAMILY TV series.  I never thought that we would see the rest of the series released to DVD after Sony dropped the ball on us a couple years ago.  I have pre ordered and am anxious to add this volume to my collection and complete the rest of the series once those volumes are available.  Shout Factory is a company that other studios could learn from!  Thanks again and I hope they will pick up the rights to another disfunctional family TV show, MAMAS FAMILY, which also seems to have been abandoned following the relase of Season 1.  Thanks to Shout and companies like it, there is always hope for future releases of abandoned seasons of your favorite TV shows!

reviewText: I TOTALLY agree with another reviewer, "geroguy" who wrote the following.  Word-for-word, it's COMPLETELY true.  Not a bit of exaggeration, unfortunately."Shout! Factory has taken this classic series, originally recorded on tape, and TRANSFERRED IT TO FILM. That alone completely destroys the integrity of the original episodes--but don't worry: they didn't stop there. They "enhanced" it. Kind of like the way going to the bathroom "enhances" one's toilet. They have HD'ed or 3-D'ed this thing to death. The result: a comedy that would've scared Hitchcock: it looks like a cartoon that's been filmed in stop-action animation--like bad Claymation. Also, the actors' body parts frequently appear to be out of proportion with one another, and the actors themselves frequently appear out of proportion with each other. (You gotta see it to believe it.) It's the creepiest, most bizarre thing I have ever seen; I can only describe the final product as grotesque."And these reviewers here who say it's a great picture-- they are simply nearly blind, or uncaring, non-discerning people at all.  Sure, "underneath," it looks like it came from great-quality masters, BUT THEN those were made into film or worse, with the wrong frames count-per second.  Watch the closing credits and EVERYBODY would agree this transfer is horrible.  The first 6 seasons were beautifully done by Sony; but this one is garbage video quality.This show was produced every year on video tape and that's why the picture quality ALWAYS looked so "new."  Whereas this 7th Season looks like film, and at the wrong speed.The only worse product is Shout! Factory's "Room 222" (both seasons 1 and 2 so far), but at least they warn you on those packages that they didn't get the greatest master tapes to start with.  Here, For "All In The Family" Seventh Season, this tape mastering job is ATROCIOUS.  Go tape the reruns of "All In The Family" 7th Season off of TV Land yourself-- literally, use VHS tapes, not even DVDs-- and you'll still have better VIDEO quality than this junk.I wish it wasn't so.  I had looked forward to this season very much and waited a long time for it.WILL SHOUT! FACTORY DO THE RIGHT THING AND RE-MASTER THESE AND REPLACE THEM FOR CUSTOMERS WHO ALREADY BOUGHT THEM, AS PARAMOUNT DID WITH ONE SEASON (ONE VOLUME ACTUALLY) OF "THE FUGITIVE"????
summary: Terrible transfer to DVD-- filmy, out-of-sync, European PAL look!

reviewText: I incorrectly mentioned in my review for the season 6 set that the Bunkers rent Gloria Bunker Stivic's(Sally Struthers) former bedroom to a Hispanic woman named Teresa Betancourt. That happens this season. Archie(the late great Carroll O'Connor) had been laid off from his job as a loading dock foreman and relied on Teresa(Liz Torres,recurringly) for his income. Edith(Jean Stapleton) was making little money at her job at the Sunshine Home,an assisted living facility occupied by disabled elderly people. Other great moments this season is where Archie,against his son-in-law Mike "Meathead" Stivic's(Rob Reiner) wishes,had Joey,Mike's and Gloria's son,now a year old,baptized in Archie's church. Not knowing Archie's beloved chair,that he had for 28 years,had a weak leg,Mike(without his moustache) accidentally breaks it just by sitting in it. Archie was so devastated by his broken chair,which Mike has(the weak leg) repaired. Gloria found it so funny seeing her husband for the first time without his moustache(since the series began Mike had it,with or without a beard). Mike grew it back shortly after shaving it off. The Bunkers and the Stivics are on a train with an annoying vagabond on board. The other episodes are great.
summary: More adventures of the Bunkers and the Stivics

reviewText: This is an interesting 7th chapter of AITF. By season 6, the neighbors the Jeffersons have moved away, and Michael and Gloria had moved into the Jeffersons' house. This is an interesting change in that Michael + Gloria are now neighbors. Sometimes the story takes place at Archie's, and sometimes at Mike and Gloria's.It is interesting that there are notably less political issues in this season and more heart. While Archie has never much liked Spanish people, he allows a Spanish medical student Theresa to stay with them until she finishes her school. And when he thinks she is being threatened, Archie violently protects her.The "Draft Dodger" has Archie in an especially angry state when he finds out Michael has invited a draft dodger to dinner. "Archie's Chair" is a sentimental but understandable episode in that Archie can NOT part with his chair even for more money than the chair is worth. "Mike + Gloria Split" is an interesting episdoe where Michael and Gloria have a fight, and Archie has to very simply explain what the problem is."Mike the Pacifist" is an especially interesting episdoe in that on a subway, Michael hates himself for punching someone. But Archie and Gloria have to explain to him that his actions were understandable in that the man shoved Gloria. (The wall between Michael + Archie is starting to break down.) We also find ourselves starting to go along with Archie's dislikes when he points out the hypcrisy of certain professions. (Medical + Legal)Archie's most shining moment here is probably in "The Unemployment Story" when he has to stop a man from jumping off a building and thus killing himself.What makes this 7th chapter of Archie's journey interesting is that not only are there less politics, but we find ourselves siding more with Archie now: "This guy is going to spend a week of taxpayer money, to write a letter and inform the guy that fired me that I'm out of work."At this 7th chapter, the series is different, but in some ways a little more interesting.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I love this show and have been waiting patiently for season 7.  I was thrilled that after 3 years of waiting, it was finally going to be released.  I can't stand SONY any more, because of their refusal to release so many of the classic TV shows that they keep in their vault, so I was happy to hear that SHOUT was taking over production.  Unfortunately, they did a terrible job of transferring the episodes to DVD.  The movements of every scene are a little bit jerky and awkward, the picture is grainy and there are horizontal lines throughout the entire picture.  Don't get me wrong, it's still a better quality than you can get by watching AITF on TVLAND, and it seems as if the episodes are unedited, but the quality is still extremely dissappointing.  If you love All in the Family, then you are still going to want to buy this collection, but be forewarned that seasons 1-6 were of much better quality.

reviewText: The 1976/77 TV season saw, along with the election of the first Democratic president in 8 years, a downfall in Norman Lear's fortunes. Sanford and Son's 6th and final season ranked a mere #27, compared to the #2 success of its heyday. Maude, now in its fifth season, had fallen out of the Top 30 after 4 seasons of Top 10 success and would be cancelled the following season. Good Times, now in its 4th season, was clinging onto the lower reaches of the Top 30 at #26, and All In The Family, after five straight seasons at #1, slipped to #12 (Happy Days became #1 this season). This was partly because in those post-Vietnam times, audiences wanted something more lightweight and less topical on TV, which they got in the form of Happy Days, Laverne and Shirley and Three's Company amongst others.1. Archie's Brief Encounter (Part 1) (22/9/76): Whilst Edith is busy at the Sunshine Home, Archie goes over to the home of Denise, his favourite waitress for something naughty... 9.5/102. Archie's Brief Encounter (Part 2) (22/9/76): Archie goes home from Denise's after a stop at Kelcy's, and his cover-up attempt backfires on Edith... 10/103. Archie's Brief Encounter (Part 3) (29/9/76): After a set-up from Mike and Gloria, Archie and Edith finally reconcile. 7/104. The Unemployment Story (Part 1) (6/10/76): Mike's article got published in a magazine, but Archie is in a foul mood after being laid off from his longtime job. 8/105. The Unemployment Story (Part 2) (13/10/76): Archie gets a new job, but the man who also applied for it becomes somewhat depressed. Also, something's not right inside Archie. 8.5/106. Archie's Operation (Part 1) (27/10/76): Archie goes to hospital to get his gallstones sorted out, only to discover he doesn't like his doctor. 9/107. Archie's Operation (Part 2) (27/10/76): Archie is finally better, and goes back to work with a raise. 8.5/108. Beverly Rides Again (6/11/76): Sick and tired of practical jokes from Pinky Peterson, Archie sets Pinky up with a date with transvestite Beverly La Salle, whose life Archie saved the previous season. 8/109. Teresa Moves In (13/11/76): Archie and Edith rent Mike and Gloria's old room to a boarder, that boarder happens to be a nurse that Archie doesn't like... 8.5/1010. Mike And Gloria's Will (20/11/76): After a freak accident at the subway, Mike is worried about Joey's future and doesn't want him to be left in the hands of Archie. 6.5/1011. Mr. Edith Bunker (27/11/76): Edith saves the life of a man at the Sunshine Home and gets a lot of positive attention, making Archie very jealous. 7.5/1012. Archie's Secret Passion (4/12/76): Edith bumps into an old high school friend at the supermarket, who married an old one-night-stand of Archie's. Now they're coming over for dinner and Archie is worried. 8/1013. The Baby Contest (11/12/76):  Mike is outraged when Archie enters Joey into a baby beauty contest against his will, but Archie gets what's coming to him later. 8/1014. Gloria's False Alarm (18/12/76): Gloria thinks she's pregnant again and as a result Mike goes for a vasectomy, but only after he realises his own hypocrisy. 9/1015. The Draft Dodger (25/12/76): An old friend of Mike's comes to the Bunker house for Christmas dinner, although a certain element of his past Archie does not approve of. Certainly not as good as a lot of fans make it out to be. 6/1016. The Boarder Patrol (8/1/77): The Bunkers come home early from their weekend getaway to find Teresa with a man in their house. 8/1017. Archie's Chair (15/1/77): Mike accidentally breaks Archie's chair, which is then purchased by an artist after accidentally making its way to Kressler's dump. 7.5/1018. Mike Goes Skiing (22/1/77): Mike is invited on a ski trip with his work mates, but it's on the same day as a party he and Gloria had already said they would attend... 8/1019. Stretch Cunningham, Goodbye (29/1/77): Archie's buddy Stretch Cunningham dies, and Archie is asked to say a few words at his funeral, not knowing Stretch was Jewish. 7.5/1020. The Joys of Sex (5/2/77): Mike and Gloria help the Bunkers with their private life after finding Edith reading a how-to book. 6/1021. Mike the Pacifist (12/2/77): After punching the lights out of a man that was harassing Gloria, Mike questions his non-violent views. 8/1022. Fire (19/2/77): There's a fire in the Bunker house, but Archie's more concerned about his possessions. 7/10.23. Mike and Gloria Split (26/2/77): Mike and Gloria temporarily split up after a heated game of Scrabble. 8/1024. Archie, The Liberal (5/3/77): When Archie's lodge is criticized for being bigoted, he recruits a black Jew into the lodge. 8.5/1025. Archie's Dog Day Afternoon (12/3/77): Archie accidentally runs over Barney Hefner's dog in his cab, but Barney doesn't think it's an accident. 7/10Average rating for first season: 7.88/10Average rating for second season: 9.03/10Average rating for third season: 9.25/10Average rating for fourth season: 9.27/10Average rating for fifth season: 9.19/10Average rating for sixth season: 7.96/10Average rating for seventh season: 7.9/10I would also like to state that the rating is for the episodes, as Shout have done a great job on this audiovisual side of the set, sure it looks a bit sharp at first, but it sure beats having lines of green and red running through the tape. Also, after the 3+ year gap between Seasons 6 and 7 (thanks Sony), I'm grateful to have seen these!
summary: Hello Jimmy Carter, goodbye Number 1 spot on the ratings
Title: N/A

reviewText: Like the previous six seasons, Season 7 of "All in the Family" continued the tradition of what was perhaps the funniest half hour on American television during the 1970s. ("Monty Python's Flying Circus" was equally funny, perhaps funnier, but that wasn't American TV.) By this point all the main characters had matured and developed, and the cast members were at their peak. Edith had become more assertive and Archie more mellow.This is the season when Archie endures an extended bout of unemployment and went into the hospital during this time for an operation, only to discover that the surgeon is a black woman. As a further twist in this episode, Archie has a rare blood type, and the surgeon offers to donate hers. (Which leads to Archie's hilarious line about being concerned that her "black shemoglobins" would mix with his "white hemoglobins.")During this season Edith arranges to have Teresa,a Puerto Rican who had been the admissions nurse at the hospital where Archie had his operation to board in the spare bedroom (that had become available because Mike and Gloria had moved out), a move that allows for some great dialogue between Archie and Teresa. (Like the episode where Archie insists that Teresa talk about "chicken chests" rather than "chicken breasts.")On a more poignant note, "The Draft Dodger" episode, which takes place around the dinner table at Christmas, involves Pinky Higgins, a friend of Archie's who has lost his son in Vietnam, and a friend of Mike's, who had fled to Canada to avoid the draft. When Archie finds out that Mike's friend is a draft dodger, he is incensed. However, the situation is defused when Pinky Higgins welcomes Mike's friend to remain, shakes his hand, and refers to him as "son."This is also the season when Stretch Cunningham dies and the family requests that Archie deliver a eulogy (or, as Archie would call it, a "urology") at Stretch's funeral. Only when he and Edith arrive at the funeral parlor do they discover that Stretch was Jewish. This leads Archie to forego his prepared eulogy (because of its Christian references) and deliver a bizarrely funny impromptu speech that manages to convey Archie's love for Stretch despite is several faux pas.All in all, some of the best episodes of the entire nine years are in Season 7.

reviewText: I thought the first half of the season may have been a bit funnier than the second, but there are still good laughs all around. Season starts off with Archie's near-affair with a waitress, a 3-parter that was a lot funnier than it sounds. Mike and Gloria's Miss America competition imitation in "The Baby Contest" is real genius, showing those two at their talented best - at other times, M & G can sometimes get on my nerves with their constant bickering.  "Beverly Rides Again", in which Beverly the drag queen that Archie saved in a previous season (not knowing she was a he) comes to visit.  The guys at Kelsey's play some good practical jokes on Archie and later its Archie's turn to pull one on them when Beverly shows up. "The Draft Dodger" is a more poignant episode when one of Mike's old draft dodging buddies steals back into the States from Canada to spend Christmas with the Bunkers.  The show still seems to be going quite strong even in its 7th season.In terms of visuals on the DVD, I didn't think things were near as serious as some reviewers made them out to be.  Worst was the opening and closing credits sequences in which the tape transfer doesn't look that great, but I didn't notice THAT much difference between this and other seasons in film quality during most of the actual episodes.  Perhaps a little, but not enough to keep me from enjoying the show.Yes, the packaging on these Shout editions is kind of cheap compared to the Season 1 - 6 original Sony editions which folded out and had a dust cover - that was quality packaging.  But if you just want to see the show, this Shout edition will get you by, and since there's nothing else out there you have to take what you can get.

reviewText: It's about time that someone had the courage to complete the task that Sony was too weak to complete.  Bravo to The Shout Factory for continuing the release of one of the best sitcoms ever made.  Actually, All in The Family may be THE best sitcom ever made.  It was the first to look at real life situations.  It dealt with race, sexuality, gender issues, violence, sexism, etc.I hope the Shout Factory takes on another controversial (although not as controversial) show, i.e., Maude.  Maude was great, and if it were not for You Tube, we'd be robbed of many of the episodes.  Also, I hope Shout Factory completes The Jeffersons.Bravo!

reviewText: I waited and waited and WAITED for AITF season seven to be released and had high hopes that Shout Factory, which usually does a great job, would pay proper respect to this great series. But they did not. Shout somehow messed up the video transfer and the picture seems to move from frame to frame with odd, jerky movements. It makes it extremely distracting to watch the show. This should not happen with a high quality transfer from the original 35 mm tapes to DVD. It's definitely a technical problem on the part of Shout and they really ought to refund every person who paid full price (like ME) to buy this DVD set and got a really awful, lower than low budget video transfer. If Shout reads this, please contact me as I am really disappointed and feel that I wasted my money. Or send me a DVD set when you correct the video transfer, to replace the one I bought. I'm only giving this 2 stars because of the horrible video transfer by Shout (All in the Family acting and scripts get 5 stars from me as it remains one of my all time favorite programs - but I can only give this Shout edition 2 stars because of the poor video transfer. Really a bad, low, very low budget type transfer.)
summary: AWFUL film transfer from Shout. Buyer Beware!

reviewText: Yes, I share the disappointment in this release because of the compression/authoring issues on this set.It's very jarring upon first viewing to see the extra-sharp picture and strange movement.However, I have found that the problem can be rectified somewhat by totally decreasing the sharpness on your TV set. While it doesn't solve the problem completely, it certainly makes the episodes much more watchable.That being said, I haven't seen many of these shows in decades and am surprised how many are better than I remember.We get less of Gloria and Meathead this season but Archie and Edith are still able to carry the show without them.O'Connor and Stapleton are still delivering on all counts and in no way are yet phoning it in. Check out the waiting room scene in "Archie's Operation" where Edith peruses a Playgirl mag. Without uttering a word, by simply turning pages, Jean Stapleton has the audience on the floor with her priceless facial expressions.It's a shame that this set is plagued with the visual problems, but it's still worth getting for a look back at when the sitcom was an art form.
summary: Compression Issues Ruin The Experience But Here's a Quick Fix

reviewText: While it is definately about time that the last 3 seasons are at least beginning to be released, it is too little too late for me. Seasons 1-6 were released almost a year to the day from each other, beginning in 2001. Season 7 SHOULD have been released over 3 years ago. With no word from Sony on why there was a delay, I tried contacting them. After a few failed attempts, I finally got an e-mail through asking why it's taking so long, and what was going on? The only response I got was "We have no plans right now to release the last 3 seasons." That was it. All I wanted was an honest answer, and I got a form letter reponse. So, I searched online and got the last 3 seasons, PLUS, the complete Archie Bunker's Place, (all 4 seasons), and as a bonus, 8 episodes of Gloria. This was from a private collection and the quality was quite good. I have no reason to buy these anymore. Sorry, but you kept us waiting, gave no reason, and I personally didn't want to wait anymore. SONY dropped the ball HUGE on this one, and I'm glad I don't have to put any money in their pockets for this.

reviewText: Like so many other fans, I was thrilled when Shout took over "All in the Family" and continued the series on dvd. The excitement came to a quick end when I received my copy and started watching it. One question: What did they do to this series? They totally ruined it. Everyone is into remastering these days and making things look better. It doesn't always work. In this case, it ruins the mood of the show. While previous seasons of this show on dvd look the same as they did on tv and retained that 70's feel to it, this season looks to have some sorta "movement problem". The actors move around and it looks artificial. The picture is extremely bright and it detracts from the original feel of the show. If I had known this is what they had planned to do, I NEVER would have purchased a copy. Needless to say, I will not be supporting the final 2 releases. Shout has reached an all-new low.
summary: Shout manages to screw up Season 7 on dvd

reviewText: Once again Sony, the slowest distribution firm in the world, is denying the fans of one of the greatest sitcoms of all time!  It's been three years since Season 6 of "All in the Family" was released so what's the hold up in releasing Seasons 7, 8 and 9 of this landmark series?  Everyone knows "All in the Family" was the Number 1 show for 5 years and stayed in the Top 10 for the remainder of it's 9 year run so there's no excuse for not releasing the remaining seasons and giving the fans what they want.  Season 7 was one of the funniest season with Archie's operation, the arrival of Theresa Betancourt as the Bunker's boarder, the demise of Stretch Cunningham and a 3 part episode in which Archie kisses another woman and how it affects his marriage to Edith.Let's hope those idiots at Sony finally wake up and release not only the rest of "All in the Family" but also the remaining seasons of "The Jeffersons", "Maude" and "One Day at a Time"!
summary: Where is Season 7 of this landmark series?!

reviewText: I own "All In The Family" seasons 1-6 which were released by Sony.Finally the complete seventh season was released by Shout Factory.I am really delighted that Shout has taken over releasing the final seasons.I just received season 7 of "All In The Family" and reviewed the episodes.The video quailty and audio quality are fantastic !!!!. The series was originally taped on videotape which resulted in a softer picture on the previous season releases.Shout Factory has done an amazing job with the season 7 release.The picture is bright,crisp,clear and colorful.The audio quality is also superb.I could not possibly be happier with the quality of the set.The content is also great.Unlike some other reviews,I believe that Archie is at his "best" in season 7.Five star quality !!!.Buy it !!!.This was television at it's best.Nothing on tv today can even hold a candle to it !!!.
summary: All In The Family season 7 finally released-Thank you Shout Factory !!!!

reviewText: Satisfactory due to having zero extra features.  But, a great show!  Carroll O'Connor and Jean Stapleton continue their excellent performances of these hilarious consistent characters.  I was too young to get the jokes when it was on originally.  But now as an adult, I'm enjoying these episodes for the first time.  Nostalgic political, religious and social commentary, but the comedy is not dated at all.  This is definitely one of the masterpieces of television history.

reviewText: That is the looming question.  Because Seasons 1 thru 6 are now officially Out of Print and discontinued by the manufactuer, I doubt if we will ever see the remaining seasons issued on DVD.  This first 6 seasons were the best of the series anyway, but it would be nice if the studio continued to issue the remaining seasons for those who want them.
summary: Will The Remaining Seasons Be Released?

reviewText: I know it's been said by many others, but I had almost given up hope of seeing another season of the best sitcom in American TV history ever being released. It was a long wait, but this is most welcome news. It makes my day. Thank you Shout Factory. Any chance you can pick up The Bob Newhart Show and finish that one, too? Barney Miller? What other neglected classics am I forgetting?

reviewText: After what seemed like an eternity, "All In The Family-Season 7" FINALLY arrives on DVD on October 5, 2010. Sony distributed the first six seasons of this landmark televison sitcom, but after 2007 that studio refused to release the last three remaining years. Thankfully, "Shout! Factory", a studio known for putting out classic shows on DVD, has bought the rights to the last three years of "All In The Family" and is dedicated in releasing seasons eight and nine.This wonderful set will come in three dics and feature all 23 episodes from the 1976-1977 season; two of those shows are hour long episodes. This was the year that many things happened to the Bunkers: Archie nearly had an affair on Edith; unemployment hits the Bunkers hard; Archie finds out he needs surgery; Gloria thinks she may be pregnant again; and Teresa moves in with the Bunkers. The sixth year also featured the best Christmas epsiode in "All In The Family's" history entitled "The Draft Dodger" where upon Archie discovers, at that Bunker's Holiday dinner, one of Mike's friends has moved to Canada to escape being drafted into the Vietnam War.The following is a list of season 7 episodes along with their airdates:1. "Archie's Brief Encounter-Part 1", Sept. 22, 19762. "Archie's Brief Encounter-Part 2", Sept. 29, 19763. "The Unemployment Story-Part 1", Oct. 6, 19764. "The Unemployment Story-Part 2", Oct. 13, 19765. "Archie's Operation", Oct. 27, 19766. "Beverly Rides Again", Nov. 6, 19767. "Teresa Moves In", Nov. 13, 19768. "Mike and Gloria's Will", Nov. 20, 19769. "Mr. Edith Bunker", Nov. 27, 197610. "Archie's Secret Passion", Dec. 4, 197611. "The Baby Contest", Dec. 11, 197612. "Gloria's False Alarm", Dec. 18, 197613. "The Draft Dodger", Dec. 25, 197614. "The Boarder Patrol", Jan. 8, 197715. "Archie's Chair", Jan. 15, 197716. "Mike Goes Skiing", Jan. 22, 197617. "Stretch Cunningham, Goodbye", Jan. 29, 197618. "The Joys of Sex", Feb. 5, 197719. "Mike The Pacifist", Feb. 12, 197620. "Fire", Feb. 19, 197621. "Mike and Gloria Split", Feb. 26, 197622. "Archie the Liberal", March 5, 197723. "Archie's Dog Day Afternoon", March 12, 1977

reviewText: It's been since February 2007 since Season 6 came outso I'm wondering (like alot of other people) what istaking so long? That's over 2 years now! We're talkingabout a show that was the NUMBER ONE SHOW on TV fromseasons 2 - season 6. That's FIVE STRAIGHT SEASONS.All In The Family did drop out of the top ten duringseason 7 but was still a popular show, so i don't seeany reason why the last 3 seasons can't be released,unless it's because season 6 didn't sell well (whichwould be unfortunate!)Season 7 did have some GOOD EPISODES. This is the seasonin which Archie had a brief fling with an attractivewaitress. Another two-part episode where Archie has tohave an operation and his nurse is African-American(HILARIOUS!,Might be my favorite of the season.) Archie also has todeliver a eulogy after his friend (Stretch Cunningham fromwork) dies suddenly. Might be the funniest eulogy you wouldever hear at a funeral.I got numerous episodes from the last three seasons on ColumbiaHOUSE home videos, but there is still several episodes that havenever even seen before, EVER, so I got an itching to own therest of the series.Please SONY, get your act together and release seasons 7,8,& 9so us fans can enjoy them. I will definitely go buy them thefirst week their out.P.S. The one star rating is because it's taking so long for thesets to come out.
summary: My Favorite HALF-HOUR SHOW - WHAT'S THE HOLD UP!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I can't for the life of me explain what happened to the 4th 5th and 6th seasons, especially the 6th (the episodes with only Mike and Gloria are just painful), well, maybe I can, in the 4th season there was far too much screen time for the unfunny neighbors the Lorenzo's although the show was still producing good shows, seasons 5 and 6 suffered greatly in the writing category.. so much so I almost passed on season 7, honestly buying it out of a sense of support for a once great show not expecting much -- but wow, this season somehow manages to come roaring back with 2 and 3 part-er episodes that are riveting character pieces not to mention flat out hilarious. Sure there are a couple of questionable character changes but I'm not complaining. If you were let down by seasons 5 or 6, please do not pass on season 7 of "the Bonkers", lol.I should add - seasons 1, 2, and 3 are my favorite sitcom seasons of all time from any show.
Title: N/A

reviewText: First of all, let me just note that I'm glad to see that this seventh season of All In The Family was released at all after such a long wait (and production company shift) since season six.  Though this season lacked the comedic bite of the first 4-5, it still is worthwhile to take a look at.The major shift in this seventh season is a (general) move away from the heated Archie/Meathead political "debates" and towards more societal/family matters, such as grandson Joey, women's liberation, and even Archie and Edith's sex life.  I have to give kudos to Norman Lear for doing this, as he realized that using the "same old rhetoric" just wouldn't work.Here's the problem: those societal issues just aren't as funny as the political stuff.  Archie vs. Mike was the stuff of legend, while the more personal topics are interesting, but don't provide that laugh-out-loud punch.  At times it is there, but those moments are much too few and far between.I liken it to "The Office" in terms of quality.  The first 4-5 seasons of that show were pure hilarity, a sixth was spotty, and (beginning with the seventh) it started to lose its gold standard.  That is almost EXACTLY the pattern of this show as well.However, it did not decrease to a point where I won't be purchasing the eighth go-'round early next year or anything like that.  I'll still be around to watch the Bunker/Stivic hilarity.
Title: N/A
